content:
7, 2013
												If you are looking at this game, odds are you are looking at the Team Fortress 2 items it unlocks as you progress through the game. And really, that's the main concept behind the game. That doesn't necessarily mean the game is "bad", just not worth replaying. Telltale does provide us with some humorous commentary from the franchises involved such as Sam & Max and Team Fortress, this keeps the game from wearing out quicker than it usually does. The poker itself is pretty unremarkable, however, but the dialogue keeps it going. As you beat your opponents and unlock items for TF2, the dialogue does lose its humor and becomes repetitive. And once you do collect the last item, there's really no reason to play again, and it seems that was Telltale was going for in this game. Unless you play TF2 (and care about cosmetic items) or are die-hard fans of the franchises, there's no reason to purchase this game. Despite this, the game is worth the price tag of $5 for the funny commentary and items you receive as you play.

												Pretty entertaining for a short while, but not for real poker players. The dialogue is great, but after a few hours when you've heard everything they have to say and it starts to get a bit repetetive, you're just frustrated by how slow the gameplay goes. There's no option to skip dialogue or animations, no shortcut keys for basic fold/call/all in actions, and the ui is generally pretty bad and exhausting for poker. The AI also doesn't appear to use any kind of machine learning. Gets kind of easy to game after a while.

content:
er 8, 2013
												If you love Texas Hold 'em and these classic video game icons, you'll love Poker Night at the Inventory! In this game you get to enjoy the many different funny dialogue from the characters Max, Strong Bad, The Heavy, and Tycho. However, if you enjoy Poker as much as I do you'll find the dialogue will become stale after a while if you play for extended periods of time. Though how frequent the characters chat can be changed in the options. If you get Poker Night solely on the purpose of playing Texas Hold 'em I would advise against it as the difficulty is novice at best. Even the harder difficulty you'll find yourself winning quite easily if you're a somewhat seasoned player of Poker. Ultimately, if you enjoy the humor and personalities of these characters and are a novice to Poker than this game is for you. If you're somebody looking for a Poker game, then I'm afraid you've come to the wrong place. 78/100

content:
6, 2014
												Seems to be a reasonable laid-back poker game that isn't after money farming, which is relatively hard to find these days in regards to the concept of gambling. Poker Night hunts after the fun factor of card games and laces it in supporting 3D aesthetics.Summary:Pros:- Consumes a great deal of time- Non-competitive- Laid back atmosphereCons:- Singleplayer only- Dialogue is repetitive- Raising difficulty by increasing odds for participants to have a good hand on drawThrough the first hours the comments of the participants are fairly hilarious but soon they get repetitive. The game's basically good to consume time for maybe an hour of play a day but that's all. It isn't really competitive on a multiplayer perspective, because it's purely singleplayer, which yet again backs up the vision that inspired the game.The gameplay is very atmospheric and sets up the sphere of a cynically comical mob saloon as a setting. If you're looking for something non-competitive outside of playing MMOs and the likes and love card games, texas hold 'em to be precise, then this is for you.I don't like how they try to make the game harder when you get further into the game by increasing the odds of your participants having a good hand. At least, that's how it feels. Gambling really isn't a level-based thing and should never be, so it's just stupid. All participants should have equal odds.

content:
ber 15, 2016
												Okay I'm one of those idiots who didn't buy it for the TF2 stuff. And I suppose having played TF2 or Sam and Max or those other ones from which the characters have taken a break to chill out and gamble their undergarments away would have made me interested in the game. I've seen most reviewers haven't spent more than 10 hours on the game so... that says a lot. Simply put, there's about a million better games out there if you just want to play poker. The dialogue is pretty good. Very distracting for the poker which makes you fun. You get roped in by a story by Max and the next thing you know you've called about 7k with a deuce and a seven.There's something quite fun about amusing, disparately rendered characters sit down next to you at the poker table. Each with their unique mannerisms and taunts. Haven't quite paid enough attention or put in enough hours to figure out if they've got their own style of play as well.The gameplay is excrutiatingly slow. Cutscene/animations and I wish there was an option to increase the play speed or keep the animations to a low like you can select for what level of dialogue you want. Mercifully though you can skip the hand if you fold and even the whole game if you're knocked out. Though the game takes quite a while to comply probably it's already mid sequence in character animations.Aside from that there's not much else. No multiplayer, no playing taking your friends money and assets or any of the good stuff. Perhaps a couple of different styles Omaha high-low or 7 card stud would have been good additions as options, without having to do too much work. The game would be worth a bit more then, but then again I brought it to play cards and already committed a capital mistake. Leading me to brand this game Poker Night at the Purgatory.

y 27
												It's ok as a game to play to just run in the background while doing other things, but it's extremely flawed. As a former professional online poker player, the game just isn't realistic. All of the computer AI players you face are terrible card players, not one is even close to being a challenge, even on hard. Many times they are just calling stations that play any 2 cards and will constantly call bets to the river with nothing. It's so easy to beat this without even trying, so in my eyes, the game isn't worth buying or playing unless you're looking to get the TF2 unlocked items.

content:
, 2014
												I've heard great things about this game. I'm sure it's a great game.I say "I'm sure" because I haven't actually played it. The game crashes on startup on my Mac. A quick look in the forums reveals that this isn't just my issue - for whatever reason, this game won't work on the Mac. That's irritating, but the fact that it's listed as a Mac-compatible game on Steam, even though the developers have said they aren't interested in fixing it, is what really steams my cheese.Bottom line - if you want to play this on a Mac, don't bother. It's a waste of five dollars that could go to starving kids in Africa, or a Subway Five-Dollar Footlong, or frankly anything other than a broken game without any promise of viability in the future.

content:
er 4, 2013
												The game in a nutshell is texas hold 'em poker played against 4 characters from various video games and comics. The game does have some problems though, of which the most noticeable is the low amount of dialogue the characters have. After having played the game for about 40 minutes the same lines will start repeating, which gets a bit annoying but luckily it can be skipped. The dialogue is pretty funny the first time you hear it but not on the second time and the other times after that.I often felt that the game should have progressed faster since you often have to wait for your turn while hearing the same dialogue over and over again. I might just be a bit impatient, but I would have liked the game more if it had a button to skip the AI's turns.The game is quite fun in short bursts but gets quite boring if played for too long. Unless you like poker a lot.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
er 1, 2013
												SHORT SUMMARY: It is fun for several hours. For $5 ($2.49 during the Steam Autumn Sale) it is EASILY worth the money.LONG SUMMARY:I found this game to be easily worth the 5$ I spent. Had I waited for the Steam Autumn Sale, I could have had this game for $2.49. Fans of wanting to play fun casual Poker will probably get the most enjoyment as the characters are fun to play against and listen to their playful banter. The interface is very simple and easy to understand.The main criticism which many have pointed out is that after several hours, the dialogue gets old and repeatable. Although it is a valid criticism, I was still able to overlook this factor as I was so focussed on the game that I was able to tune it out. If players find it too difficult to tune out, there are actual audio controls that let you decide how much dialogue you want or players can flat out turned off the dialogue. Although the game could have used more dialogue, Considering that this was TTG's first attempt at a Poker game like this, I can find this shortcoming forgiveable.This is a game where the unlocks are a fun challenge. The Steam achievements are also equally fun to acquire. These both combined is what made the game really fun for me. They are both hard to acquire, but not in a unrealistic or frustrating way. It makes you want to get them all no matter how many games or hands you have to play.    Depending on how good of a Poker player you are, if this game is played on Normal, it should not take too many hours to unlock all the game features which can cut the lifespan of this game. However, I found that if I play this game on Hard difficulty, it really extended the life of this game. On Hard, I felt like I was playing against smart poker players that were able to mathematically make smart decisions while also making bluffs or even calling your bluffs. The Hard setting is the perfect difficulty fun wise.This game lacks on-line multi-player. However, knowing that I only paid $5 for this game, I definitely was not expecting that feature. To be honest, I was quite fine with this exclusion as I found this game to be more fun that way. Since this game does not use real money, human players can often not take the game serious and make ridiculous decisions.Beyond the unlocks and achievements, this game has a longer life span than people think. No 2 games are ever the same (aside from the dialogue). Overall for 5$, I got more than my money worth from this game and enjoyed playing with characters from various media genres. There is no question Tell Tale will only improve on this fun unique Poker concept.

content:
er 1, 2013
												SHORT SUMMARY: It is fun for several hours. For $5 ($2.49 during the Steam Autumn Sale) it is EASILY worth the money.LONG SUMMARY:I found this game to be easily worth the 5$ I spent. Had I waited for the Steam Autumn Sale, I could have had this game for $2.49. Fans of wanting to play fun casual Poker will probably get the most enjoyment as the characters are fun to play against and listen to their playful banter. The interface is very simple and easy to understand.The main criticism which many have pointed out is that after several hours, the dialogue gets old and repeatable. Although it is a valid criticism, I was still able to overlook this factor as I was so focussed on the game that I was able to tune it out. If players find it too difficult to tune out, there are actual audio controls that let you decide how much dialogue you want or players can flat out turned off the dialogue. Although the game could have used more dialogue, Considering that this was TTG's first attempt at a Poker game like this, I can find this shortcoming forgiveable.This is a game where the unlocks are a fun challenge. The Steam achievements are also equally fun to acquire. These both combined is what made the game really fun for me. They are both hard to acquire, but not in a unrealistic or frustrating way. It makes you want to get them all no matter how many games or hands you have to play.    Depending on how good of a Poker player you are, if this game is played on Normal, it should not take too many hours to unlock all the game features which can cut the lifespan of this game. However, I found that if I play this game on Hard difficulty, it really extended the life of this game. On Hard, I felt like I was playing against smart poker players that were able to mathematically make smart decisions while also making bluffs or even calling your bluffs. The Hard setting is the perfect difficulty fun wise.This game lacks on-line multi-player. However, knowing that I only paid $5 for this game, I definitely was not expecting that feature. To be honest, I was quite fine with this exclusion as I found this game to be more fun that way. Since this game does not use real money, human players can often not take the game serious and make ridiculous decisions.Beyond the unlocks and achievements, this game has a longer life span than people think. No 2 games are ever the same (aside from the dialogue). Overall for 5$, I got more than my money worth from this game and enjoyed playing with characters from various media genres. There is no question Tell Tale will only improve on this fun unique Poker concept.

content:
ber 11, 2016
												Poker Night at the Inventory isn't an all encompassing poker game. You can only play no limit Texas Hold 'em, and you always face the same four opponents. But playing poker is only half, hell, maybe less, of Poker Night's appeal. The real reason people should go out right now and pick up developer Telltale's latest effort is for the characters. Poker Night is hilarious, featuring cleverly written banter coming from some of nerd culture's more recognizable faces. Poker Night is a Texas Hold 'em simulation with four choice characters from gaming culture. Players join Tycho of Penny Arcade fame, The Heavy from Team Fortress 2, Homestar Runner's Strong Bad, and Max from Sam and Max at a table in a secret poker club called the Inventory. After a brief introduction to the club the player is at the table with the characters, playing Hold 'em until they either beat everyone or go out. Occasionally the other characters will have no money to put up, and will offer collateral, which can be used for aesthetic reskinning of items for various TF2 classes. Winning enough hands also unlocks new tables and poker decks for use, but doesn't change the type of poker you play. You always play with the same people and everyone always starts out with $10,000. That's it. That's the entirety of what you'll experience as far as gameplay is concerned in Poker Night. If you lose, you just start another game. Over time the funny dialogue will start to lose its charm as it repeats, but you can limit it or turn it off completely after you've heard all there is to hear over the course of a few hours. It'd be easy to feel disappointed, or cheated by how short a time it takes to hear all the jokes, but the reality is that this is a small, five dollar download. It comes with all the polish I'd expect from Telltale, and while it only features Texas Hold 'em, is a really entertaining way to kill some time, especially if you want those TF2 unlocks. It may not be the best poker game out there, but it is definitely the funniest. And, as most people will tell you, a little humor goes a long way.

												Prepare for a different kind of poker night in a very different kind of club. In Poker Night at the Inventory, you'll deal with notable characters such as Penny Arcade's clever, cunning Tycho, Team Fortress 2's hulking Heavy, Homestar Runner's self-proclaimed "awesome icon" Strong Bad and the hyperkinetic "rabbity-thing" from Sam & Max. These characters come together in ways some never thought possible, in a setting few would have predicted. You'll experience a new style of poker, particularly when hands don't go the way of the other fiery competitors at the table ... because these players have left a trail of victims in their wake a mile long -- with heavy weapons, biting sarcasm and irony -- and when they sit down at the table for Poker Night at The Inventory, they're ready to go all in!Poker Night at The Inventory features fully voiced characters utilizing Telltale’s dynamic dialog system. All the characters will talk trash, give unique tells, and react to the game dynamically as it is being played, providing a unique experience with each round played.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
y 4, 2015
												Love the game as a poker game, taught me how to play poker.I jumped into this game not knowing how to play a slither of poker, I just sat down, and played and played for a couple hours, got the TF2 items, and had fun. I would play again. The characters are funny, there are unlockable decks, the whole game comes together really well, and for you who buy it for the items, heres a quick step by step wayEasy Way To Get Poker ItemsStep 1: Start Game.Step 2: If there's no special item in the ante, hit ESC then hit the right arrow twice and select a new game.Step 3: Repeat Step 2 until an item is ante'd.Step 4: On the first hand, go all in no matter what hand you have.Step 5: If the person who's item is up for grabs didn't go in with your all in, keep doing all in's until you get him to play your matching hand.Step 6: If you lose at anytime during step 5, repeat up to step 5 again.Step 7: If the person with the ante'd up item plays against your all in bet in the first hand and loses, you automatically get the item without having to go 30 hands into the game only for Strongbad to pull pocket Aces out of nowhere and put on his cool face.This in no way means don't enjoy Poker Night the way you want to, this is just the fastest way to get the unlocks for those who don't want to sit through hours of poker.

content:
23, 2012
												Not bad. About 10 hours of playtime, less if you just want the TF2 stuff, more if you want to unlock everything. This of course, depends on your luck, but that's what I ended up with. Dialogue is funny, graphics are okay, just pretty decent in general. With one major problem. For a poker game, they sure forgot how to play poker. Fairly often, I'll see games where there are more than four of a kind. I'll have an ace of spades, max will have an ace of spades as well, causing me to facepalm. When one makes a poker game, people would expect they know how to play poker. I've had times where I've had four of a kind, only to see Tycho has several of the same cards. Despite this major problem, the game is still pretty fun and good for the price. 8/10

content:
21, 2014
												Prepare for a different kind of poker night in a very different kind of club. In Poker Night at the Inventory, you'll deal with notable characters such as Penny Arcade's clever, cunning Tycho, Team Fortress 2's hulking Heavy, Homestar Runner's self-proclaimed "awesome icon" Strong Bad and the hyperkinetic "rabbity-thing" from Sam & Max. These characters come together in ways some never thought possible, in a setting few would have predicted. You'll experience a new style of poker, particularly when hands don't go the way of the other fiery competitors at the table ... because these players have left a trail of victims in their wake a mile long -- with heavy weapons, biting sarcasm and irony -- and when they sit down at the table for Poker Night at The Inventory, they're ready to go all in!Poker Night at The Inventory features fully voiced characters utilizing Telltale’s dynamic dialog system. All the characters will talk trash, give unique tells, and react to the game dynamically as it is being played, providing a unique experience with each round played.

content:
y 4, 2015
												Love the game as a poker game, taught me how to play poker.I jumped into this game not knowing how to play a slither of poker, I just sat down, and played and played for a couple hours, got the TF2 items, and had fun. I would play again. The characters are funny, there are unlockable decks, the whole game comes together really well, and for you who buy it for the items, heres a quick step by step wayEasy Way To Get Poker ItemsStep 1: Start Game.Step 2: If there's no special item in the ante, hit ESC then hit the right arrow twice and select a new game.Step 3: Repeat Step 2 until an item is ante'd.Step 4: On the first hand, go all in no matter what hand you have.Step 5: If the person who's item is up for grabs didn't go in with your all in, keep doing all in's until you get him to play your matching hand.Step 6: If you lose at anytime during step 5, repeat up to step 5 again.Step 7: If the person with the ante'd up item plays against your all in bet in the first hand and loses, you automatically get the item without having to go 30 hands into the game only for Strongbad to pull pocket Aces out of nowhere and put on his cool face.This in no way means don't enjoy Poker Night the way you want to, this is just the fastest way to get the unlocks for those who don't want to sit through hours of poker.

3, 2015
												It's very simple and fun, especially for fans of all series colliding here. Although I am terrible at poker.There are simple tells and such to the characters.Max: Bluffs and bets, don't encourage him because it's hard to tell if there's a good hand behind the chips.Strong Bad: Huge bully that only bets and raises when there is competency to it, although most likely if he has a bad hand after the flop it's more outrageous.Heavy: Competent player, but has obvious tells and is programmed to start and compete in betting wars. This goes on even if his hand is complete trash.Tycho: Demon from the Nth dimension who sits in the corner until he has a hand capable of destroying the entirety of the universe, in which case he bets more money than Las Vegas can hope to scam people out of. Most likely the second or last guy you'll face and then he'll demolish you by whittling all your cash away and then killing you with a good hand.You know, fun stuff.

content:
19, 2013
												Poker Night at the Inventory is a well-implemented poker game, where you play no limit Texas Hold 'em.Your opponents are Tycho (Penny Arcade), The Heavy (Team Fortress 2), Strong Bad (Homestar Runner) and Max (Sam and Max).Poker Night's main part are the dialogues between the characters. However, you must be familiar with the characters in order to understand many of the jokes.After a while the funny dialogue will start to lose its charm as it repeats, but you can limit it or turn it off completely after you have heard all there is to hear.You can unlock new tables and poker decks for use and also you can unlock four aesthetic items for various TF2 classes.The biggest issue with the game is that there is no multiplayer option. You always play with the same opponents and everyone always starts out with $10,000.Well it is a simple game with four well known video game superstars and gives you the chance to earn TF2 items while you are playing. For that low price you can not make a mistake with a purchase.Sound 7/10Graphics 8/10Gameplay 6/10Atmosphere 7/10If you liked my review, please feel free to follow me and/or my curator group:http://steamcommunity.com/id/Ov3RT4K3R/myworkshopfiles/?section=guideshttp://steamcommunity.com/groups/orcollective#curationAlso feel free to check out my YouTube Channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC83DYCmrWfl9ttrhX54jmWA

number of helpful: 6 of 14 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
r 22, 2015
												I honestly can't recommend this game.  It's not that it's a bad game, but the poker AI is just atrocious.  Here's a typical scenario:  I have pocket jacks pre-flop and I'm on the button.  First to act raises.  I re-raise.  Small blind goes all in.  Big blind goes all in.  First to raise goes all in.  I fold because in a real poker game, I'm guaranteed to be beat at this point.  They all turn over their cards: 10 4 off suit, 2 3 suited, and 8 5 off suit.  What the hell?!  This is not a realistic poker situation, even for beginners.  You would think playing people who are this reckless would be easy, but oh no!  Pretty much anytime I have a legit hand that I'm confident in, every single player will call my bets/ raises.  Consequently, the power of numbers works against me and the majority of the time the AI sucks out with a terrible hand.  And if you play tight, all that happens is that the other four players play reckless and they end up giving all of their chips to a single player who will now have a 4:1 stack lead over you.  That's pretty hard to overcome.  On the plus side, the animations are great and the conversation by the players is truly entertaining (minus Tycho, who comes across as extremely annoying).  If you're a fan of any of the characters/ franchises included in this game, I would recommend picking this up as that part is rather entertaining.  If you're looking for a good solid poker game however, I would avoid this as the AI is simply terrible and you will spend most of your time frustrated by it.  I would give this a 5.5/10.

r 16, 2014
												If you are buying this game with the intent of playing poker, don't bother. The AI is laughable, and not challenging in the slightest once you've learned how the bots think. The voice acting is decent, although the continuous dialog gets obnoxious quickly. On the bright side, the achievements are all relatively easy to unlock, with the exception of straight flush and four of a kind.. which are just luck based. If you're interested in this game soley for the tf2 items, it may still be worth the purchase. Just view it as paying a dollar an item or so, and if that's still worth it to you, then have at it. I'd say it's best viewed as buying an items dlc for team fotress two, rather than a game purchase - you'll be less likely to end up disappointed in that case.

content:
y 12, 2012
												First I'll ask a question: Who the hell still plays this game?The hype from TF2 unlockable items has ended, and therefore nobody plays Poker Night anymore. Poker Night at the Inventory is a largely failed attempt at having a game surviving soley on writing and humor. Failed because of their choice of crossover NPC's to play against, be it either Strongbad's narcissistic napolean complex or Tycho's sarcastic condescending passive-aggressive attitude. Nothing good can be said about gameplay, because it's nothing but Texas Hold-em, which you can play in real life for free. But if you REALLY want to get TF2 items from cards, then get friends together and play online or real-life poker where each of you wagers one of your hats, that would make for a more enjoyable time than listening to four wise-♥♥♥ NPC's talk smack about you.

												Poker Night is one of the best poker games out there ( as many as there are ). So the basics are youre at the inventory and you have a friendly match of poker with the familiar faces like the Heavy from team fortress 2, Tycho from Penny arcade, Strong bad and Max . There only one mode Texas hold em and its still okay. With the really nice looking style and the awesome poker mechanics and the items for TF2 hounds its a match made in heaven if you have the spare money this is well worth the buy I give it a 7/10

content:
er 24, 2010
												You may be saying to yourself, "WELL GEE KILLZ OBVIOUSLY YOU ARE RECOMMENDING THIS FOR THE TF2 ITEMS," put your rant on hold. Yes the final straw for this game was the TF2 items because I didn't know the rules of poker and how to play. I myself personally love both the Heavy and Max (the bunny from Sam & Max) so I had this game on thought for a while. I honestly can say that even after getting the TF2 unlocks, I can't stop playing this game. The dialogue is not only pure gold, but the music of the Inventory is outstanding and really sets the atmosphere for this game. Telltale didn't just mess around by putting 4 characters together you can play poker with, they actually put strong and believable dialogue that actually makes you feel like you are playing poker with this strange set of people instead of just characters in a video game. It's clever, it's hysterical, and it's $5. Texas Hold 'Em is really easy to learn and you'll have a great time learning the game.

content:
y 8, 2014
												Poker Night at the Inventory is a fun and simple Texas Hold'em simulator featuring familiar faces from various games offered on Steam.  If you like playing computer opponents in poker, this is fun and humorous.  There is no multiplayer function.  The game loses it's humor fast, and there isn't any DLC, so replay value is pretty low.  Unlike the sequel to this game, there are no DLC to win by playing this game.  Overall, it is just alright, but not spectacular.

Either one: You want to play poker with some video game characters (Really?) or two: you want promo items in Team Fortress 2.I got this crap for #2.Cons -The game seems.... VERY unrealistic at times, as in, 6 Aces played in a single game kind of unrealistic (This has happened).Boring. After about 30 minutes, you understand what to do. Either play like these are REAL people and bet like a real person, or you trick the bots into 'thinking' you got good cards (There ARE guides out there to 'farm' the items off the characters: go all in EVERY TIME).Poker Night is painful. The bots know exactly what your cards are, but they just play along. Their cards sometimes (4/5) have most of your cards. $5 - $10 for petty gameplay and items.The some of the items are not very good either, For instance, the Liscence to Maim looks like an upgraded Merc. Badge.Pros +TF2 Items.Fun dialogue. The characters DO have some fun chit-chat with each other.

content:
er 19, 2014
												Ok so firstly, if you are here for TF2 items then do not buy this game. The money isnt worth the TF2 items and when you buy the game it takes forever to get the items. Secondly, if you are looking for fun, look somewhere else, this game has low graphics and boring characters. Poker can be played on the internet for free.When you are aiming to get TF2 items in this game, you need to play poker for hours and hours and you must win in order to obtain the items. In this game, you must play poker and beat the other 4 players in order to win. There are 5 players in total: Yourself, Max, Strong Bad, The Heavy and Tycho. In order to win items you must keep playing games until you encounter someone coughing up some gear but you need to defeat that player and if anyone else defeats the player you lose the item. The items take forever to encounter and you have a low chance of winning the item. It take several hours or maybe even days to obtain them all. I have encountered items before but never received them.This game is not recommended unless you have fine skills at poker and you are desperate for these items. It is an absolute waste of money if you are trying to get the items. 4/10Chop2014

												This is a good value if you, like me, love No Limit Texas Hold 'Em and are already a fan of most (or all) of these characters. It's a bonus if you, like me, also happen to own Team Fortress 2 on Mac or PC, as some of Poker Night's unlockables are useable in that game. I played for two hours yesterday and already feel like I got my $5 worth of gaming. Compare this to Portal 2 (which I also recommend) at $50 for around 15 hours of gameplay.

, 2013
												It's poker, plain and simple. The trick here is with the characters, an amusing round of funny and not-so-funny lines. The characters themselves are alright, as is the dialogue. Unfortunately just not enough to hold my interest for long, especially with the second game out. There were some great moments, but they were kind of few and far between. Still, a good poker game and decent variety and options. 6/10

3, 2013
												An overall decent Texas Hold'em simulator, but the real stars here are your opponents, seeming almost randomly selected based on their backgrounds: Max from the Sam & Max franchise, Strongbad of Homestar Runner, The Heavy from Team Fortress 2, and Tycho of Penny Arcade. Telltale Games has outdone themselves creating an immersive experience with these third party characters, matching their personality to a T when it comes to dialogue and interactions: Max tells stories about fighting crime with Sam, Strongbad rants and raves just like with his email videos, Heavy thinks of the chips as his 'team' and blames the Spy whenever he gets a bad hand, and Tycho makes various different tabletop, card, and video game references. They play the game exactly like you would expect them to, which is a great feat in itself considering the licensing TTG must have had to go through. Even though Poker Night 2 is on the horizon and to be released this month, the original should not be overlooked. There are still special crossover TF2 items to be unlocked, and you won't be seeing any of the original cast (aside from cameos by Max) in the sequel. Definitely worth the buy.

9, 2013
												This game is a pleasent little time waster. Something to occupy an uneventful evening where you don't want to play anything strenuous but don't want to feel numb in what you do play. Its relaxing but still can be a mental challenge, with a bit of witty humour thrown in for good measure.Now I only wish this wasn't the last hooraw for Strong Bad and most importantly Homestarrunner.com. With the exception of a Christmas special in '10 this was the last I seen or heard from the Brothers Chaps. Its truely a shame, I thought that if anything their cartoons and humour were getting BETTER!! I felt Homestar was finally starting to crawl out of Strong Bad's shadow and become something more than a dimless retard, but an excitable spaz that isn't entirely aware of where he is or what he says but still a very plucky gogetter......*SIGH*Go play this game

er 7, 2011
												PresentationPoker Night reveals 4 gaming characters playing a game of what seems to be Texas Hold em. all you have is 3 buttons. An easy way to play a poker video game. The characters are funny and it doesn't make it your typical boring poker game.GraphicsThe graphics are nothing you should care for this game. But the images are polished and nothing looks bad.GameplayI do not know much about how Poker games work but it seems like this kind of poker  (texas hold em) is more of a dumbed down version. Almost like a version for kids or something. But you only play by clicking 3 buttons, Fold, Call/check, Bet/Raise. And its mostly by luck. However, this makes it the simple of Poker games.Lasting AppealIts a 5 dollar game with some interesting dialogue and easy gameplay. I recommand this for Team Fortress 2 players who are in need of new items for their collection whatsoever.  RATING : 8.3

												I tried Poker Night 1 and 2, and 1 is the more-fun game.  The personalities in 2 are a little annoying, and the gameplay isn't balanced among the players (Ash won the first 8 pots I played, usually bluffing, but he had the nuts every time he was called down).  It's a fun game for a pretty cheap price, and all of the characters have their quirks that are a lot of fun.  There is one pretty huge bug: you can't seem to min-raise pre-flop.  If everyone calls a 600 big blind and it comes to you, your min-raise button says "$1,200 total", but using it raises $1,200 to $1,800 total.  I'm not sure if this happens 100% of the time or just in certain conditions, but it was certainly repeatable for me.

er 11, 2013
												Poker Night at the Inventory:It is a Texas hold 'em single player only game featuring: Strong Bad from Homestar Runner,  The Heavy from Team Fortress 2, Max from Sam & Max, Tycho from Penny Arcade and you.The NPC players play similar to their personalities. The Heavy is very aggressive frequently going all in with poor hands etc. Another interesting aspect the the NPC players are not of all the same skill level with players like The Heavy often being one of the first ones out and Max being one of the last two. At the beginning of a game each there is a chance one of the NPCs will bet a Team Fortress 2 item which is a nice touch and adds an incentive to continue playing the game after the first three or four games.The game attempts to draw the player in by having lots of back and forth talking between the NPC players and it does this quite well with enough dialogue to keep it from getting repetitive too quickly but after several games it will get repetitive as you start to hear the same things for the fourth and fifth times. Games also take a while to play out due to the amount of talking during the games. You can click to skip past the speaking which helps sometimes but also gets old after a while. There are options in the settings menu to prevent them from triggering speech scenes that delay play until they are complete or turn off speech completely but doing so removes the main focus of the game. If you are going for the Team Fortress 2 items it may get frustrating as winning is not enough to get them. You must be the one to knock the NPC betting their item out of the game and often none of the NPCs will bet an item resulting in some reloading if you just are only after them.Overall I found it a fun experience. The dialogue was amusing but does get repetitive. The poker play was solid and the NPCs having different play styles combined with the Team Fortress 2 items add some replayability. As of writing this the list price is $5 and at that price I felt it was worth the cost.

												Honestly I just bought the game because it was on sale once for 0,99€ and I was intrigued by the TF2 items. After playing for a while I realized that the game is more that just a cash-in on in-games items. It actually has a lot of humor and you'll probably get a good laugh from the dialog between the characters, if you know them of course.The TF2 awards are actually really satisfying to win, because it isn't just handed to you for buying the game. No, you have to win it. Thus making this game really enjoyable, it feels like you're actually getting something out of it. It drives you into wanting to win a poker match and dread losing because you have to start over again.Do not worry to much about not knowing poker, I still have no idea what I'm doing. The game actually helps you to understand a thing or two neatly without forcing you trough some dumb tutorial.5€ is still an okay price, you'll probably get a lot of fun out of it even if you're just in it for the TF2 stuff.8/10

1, 2011
												Filled with absurb humour and fun poker playing at a reasonable price, Poker Night at The Inventory is a good game for anyone who is a fan of poker, Homestar Runner, Sam 'n Max, Penny Arcade or Team Fortress 2. Perhaps especially so with Team Fortress 2. The game features several interesting (if cosmetic) unlockables at less than Mann Co. Store prices, when taken all together. Combined with the fact that you're getting a free game, it's worth it to any 'hard-core' TF2 fan. Besides, you may find you enjoy the game of Texas Hold'Em on its own merits.As for me, I think the biggest factor going for the game is the humor value. The characters are lovable, the unlocks good for a giggle or two, but overall, the conversations are the most interesting aspect of this game. I sincerely hope there will be a sequel, preferably with a few more characters. (TF2 Unlocks optional, frankly.)While I am blue skying though, I wish people would buy in with collateral after you have already won it.

I have barely any clothes, it was a miracle they let me in the library. I have no wife or children, they left me. Every day is a constant battle, where I am fighting suicide. er 14, 2015
												Not a lot to say here. It's poker with a decent amount of banter between the players. The playstyle of the players mostly fits their character, though I never did figure out Max's playstyle. He was also the most fun of the characters banter-wise; Tycho is just a ♥♥♥♥ and not in any amusing way, and the Heavy and Strong Bad are both really one-note characters. The best moments are them playing off each other, and that's done fairly well, but eventually there's so little new dialogue left to hear that you're mostly stuck hearing the same things over and over.As for the gameplay, it's... poker. The AI is decent. I hardly noticed a difference between normal and hard. The only other gameplay thing I could mention are the achievements, which are... mostly luck-based. I'm not interested in grinding them out, at least, and I'm not really interested in playing this any further, either.For the low price point, I'd say it's worth it for a few hours of fun and banter, and you'd probably get more out of it if you were a poker nut, which I'm definitely not, but... yeah, alright.

, 2013
												Poker Night pits you against four arguably famous characters in a game of Texas Hold 'Em for virtual cash you don't have to pay for. Essentially, you can waste as much as you wish, as the game is centered around fun and character rather than actual high-stakes Poker.The highlight of this game is the dialogue between characters. Even if you don't know Max, Tycho, Strong Bad or Heavyweapons Guy, you'll quickly learn that each of them are mentally ill in their own fun, quirky little way.Oh, and you learn how to play Texas Hold 'Em. Don't worry, you'll get the hang of it. The game's really luck-based, so just know what you can do and hope for the best.Poker Night at the Inventory is $4.99 USD. In game prizes can be used in Team Fortress 2 as well. Visit the store page for more details.

												Honestly, I just got it so I could win the "Iron Curtain". Not to mention it was only $5. But after having played it for a while, I realize it's some serious fun. I've never been good at Texas Hold'em, but this is beginning to help me learn. :3 One of the best parts of the game, though, is the idle chatter the characters have at the table. You can set the game to have them talk often or barely at all, which is also nice. There's also a lot ot unlock, from TF2 swag to decks and table themes. Not just for fans of Poker, I think anyone who plays videogames will enjoy this.Between you and me, though - I play it without the bleeps. ;D Tycho's got quite the mouth on him.

												I originally bought it for the tf2 items, but then realized its actually a really fun game. Though i wasnt playing for fun until after i got the items since they can be hard to get if you dont have a good hand.Good:-Funny and entertaining dialogue between the characters-Free items! (that is, unless you bought this game solely for the items)-if you lose a game you can watch the rest of them finish it if you want to,and the best part? you get to see their hands!-You can unlock many tables and decks to customize your game (doesnt affect gameplay of course,but still cool.)-you get a little poker nickname after each win (or loss) depending on how much you have (or owe)Bad:- fresh dialogue seems to run out after about 2 hours and most lines repeat, though some new lines still pop up here and there.Tips:-If you are here for the items but dont want to play normal games, press Escape go to the menu and keep clicking new tournament, keep clicking it until somone doesnt throw money and throws an item in instead-if your playing a normal game try to knockout tycho first because trust me you DO NOT want to be alone at the table with tycho, he will put you through hell.Overall: Just a very fun game, especially for just 5$

30, 2016
												I'mma be straight forward here: Only 2 of the main 4 characters you play Texas Hold 'Em Against I actually know of, only because of their popularity of their franchises (Sam and Max, and TF2), the other two aren't as popular or well known, so that's one flaw. Two, the item system is complete random, so it could take at least 10 minutes of you either restarting the match just for one of them to offer an item instead of money in the beginning cutscene, or try and be VERY patient and keep losing/ winning until one of them offers an item. HOWEVER, even if they do offer one, if you lose your entire hand, or they lose theirs to someone ELSE, you won't get the item. Anyways, the main flaws are: Poor random choice in a few characters, overall game mechanics, and the lack of weapons in the game that actually have use, like stat-weapons like the Spy-cicle, and the only cool item you unlock (personally in my opinion) is the Enthusiast's Timepiece. What would have made this much better, is if all characters were always random TF2 characters, with them betting items more often (since the weapons won in the games go into your TF2 file). I wouldn't really recommend it, since the only main reason why I got the game (from a trade) was because I wanted the Timepiece watch because let's be honest here, who wouldn't want a SOLID GOLD invisibility watch, that has a symbol representing video games' most iconic character of all time, PAC-MAN!? Overall, 4/10.

r 9, 2015
												Pokr Night at the Inventory is a game about - Well, poker. You play at a place called the Inventory, Kinda like a bar for video game characters. Probably the main aesthetic to this game is that you play with four players, all from different games. Even if you (Somehow) dont know any of these people its still a great and worthwhile expirience. Fortunatly, unlike most card games out there, its not stale and boring. The characters chat and make references to their own or other peoples games, which I liked ALOT. And with quirky animations, customisation of decks, varing difficulty, trading cards and achievments - all at a low price, you'd be stupid not to pick up this title.You also get free tf2 Stuff.Basically why 90% of people buy it.Not even kidding.

r 13, 2015
												Never in my life did I see myself playing poker, mother effing poker!Whenever I spot poker, It's either a $#!@ facebook or mobile game that is so plain and mundane I want to vomit.But this game, it's special, the depth and personality of the characters are just so funny and realistic, I won't blame you if you'd ditch your real life friends for these 4 lads, who may come out rude at times, but in the end they just want to have fun (Any your money)! That's not the only pro, there was just a big telltale sale you could get this game for less than a dollar, the unique and indulging gameplay+ the promotional tf2 items. It's true many people only buy it for the unlocks, but I myself still play it even after all the promotional weapons/cosmetics, the game's just that good to leave. Plus, it's a telltale game, you should expect quality and fun for hours if not days.The only con would be the limited playtime, as the game can be a bit short and boring after haring all the dialogue and obtaining all the items. To mostly avoid this for the most part I'd suggest taking moderate breaks and trying to enjoy yourself, and not hunt for the items. Good luck, good day, and have fun!

14, 2013
												While the premise of a card game turned computer game might not make everyone jump hight out of their seats and pre-order it, the addition of a great cast, entertaining dialogue, and unlockable prizes (such as different decks and tables) along with achievement items for Team Fortress 2 makes this game worth checking out.You find yourself at a place known as the Inventory, a special speakeasy made during the prohibition for game enthusiasts who only wanted to have a drink, play a few games, and bet ridiculous amounts of money. Nowadays, the place still has it's fair share of strange patrons such as Max, Strong Bad, Heavy, and Tycho.The guest stars aren't just around for show, they keep the games interesting and will sometimes offer to buy in using special items that are handed over to whoever knocks them out of the game. These prizes are:Max: Lugermorph and License to Maim (custom pistol and police badge)Strong Bad: Dangeresque, Too? (moonviewer glasses)Heavy: Iron Curtain (custom minigun)Tycho: Enthusiast's Timepiece (custom invisiwatch)This game, while laughing and carefree in nature, will punish those who get too greedy when one of the coveted items comes into play. It make take a few tries, but the slow and cunning method will always triumph of rushing recklessly (except in Max's case, he doesn't even look at the cards).

er 27, 2011
												I wasn't expecting a whole lot from this game, I'll be honest. I thought that Texas Hold 'Em with Tycho, Strong Bad, Max, and the Heavy would be a little too gimmicky. Still, with the promise of TF2 items and a liking of Poker, it drew me in. Gameplay is... Well, it's Poker. Texas Hold 'Em, to be exact. If you don't know how to play, there's a tutorial available in-game, along with a handy couple of charts explaining betting and card hand heirarchy. The characters chat with each other as you play, (and you can actually determine how much they talk in the game's options menu) and as a fan of Team Fortress 2 and Penny Arcade, some of the conversations were pretty amusing to hear. I have to admit that my interest has been piqued in Sam & Max's Adventures, along with.. Whatever it is Strong Bad is from because of them.All in all, if you can get it cheap, and you like TF2 items or maybe you just like poker, I don't see a reason why you shouldn't at least give it a whirl.

y 15, 2016
												Fun when your bored, a decent poker simulation with a video game twist, only issue is the game encourages you to buy everyone drinks to get them to show hints about their cards.  While the idea is great, the actual results are not, the players give little to no increase in body language, and the few movements they do make tell litterally nothing.  This makes the game a challenge at times and is largely based on luck.  But besides that I quite enjoyed the game even though the reason I bought it was the tf2 items.  The characters have their respective personalities but as with real humans they can be quite unpredictable.  One minute you might bluff and go all in and everyone folds, then you do it again in an entirely different game and everyone goes all in too and you get completely demolished.  It's one game where the RNG system is actually fun.  7.92/10 -Scale of edgy approval

												Pokr Night at the Inventory is a game about - Well, poker. You play at a place called the Inventory, Kinda like a bar for video game characters. Probably the main aesthetic to this game is that you play with four players, all from different games. Even if you (Somehow) dont know any of these people its still a great and worthwhile expirience. Fortunatly, unlike most card games out there, its not stale and boring. The characters chat and make references to their own or other peoples games, which I liked ALOT. er 26, 2013
												The poker is alright, but since it's all funny money, the stakes actually feel pretty low. Almost better off taking a loss on the first hand, while trying to set up for a quicker win in case the all in succeeds. Poker isn't what you're here for though. The game is worth it for the witty and crude banter offered by the different chaps you sit down with. Unfortunately, one of the folks responsible for this game being on Steam decided it would be a great idea to make getting a winning Straight Flush an achievement. Nobody saw fit to mention that it can take several thousand hands to see one flippin Straight Flush. If you're worried about completing the achievements, and the rest are far more reasonable, that one achievement or maybe the Four of a Kind will have you sitting through the dialog til you can't stand to hear the interesting-the-first-time characters one more time. You'll be less sane than the lot of em. Good luck. The poker 3/5, add in the banter 4/5.

												All-in-all I will admit, I bought the game for the items. Who wouldn't? But by playing the game, it's actually really fun and funny. 4, 2016
												Well, there's not much to say... I mean, where can't you find a poker game available nowadays? This is just another variation, where you can get to play with some characters from different games who're always trying to make jokes about this and that. It's interesting when you play at the first time but then it gets old when they start repeating the same things over and over again. Besides that there're also some goals to achieve and if you do, you can get to unlock items to certain games, such as Team Fortress 2 (it was actually one of the biggest reasons that motivated me to purchase this title). Although there're achievements to get, unfortunately so far there aren't any trading cards available but I sure hope that they can add some in the future. Overall, if you enjoy playing poker, go for it.

y 15, 2016
												Fun when your bored, a decent poker simulation with a video game twist, only issue is the game encourages you to buy everyone drinks to get them to show hints about their cards.  While the idea is great, the actual results are not, the players give little to no increase in body language, and the few movements they do make tell litterally nothing.  This makes the game a challenge at times and is largely based on luck.  But besides that I quite enjoyed the game even though the reason I bought it was the tf2 items.  The characters have their respective personalities but as with real humans they can be quite unpredictable.  One minute you might bluff and go all in and everyone folds, then you do it again in an entirely different game and everyone goes all in too and you get completely demolished.  It's one game where the RNG system is actually fun.  7.92/10 -Scale of edgy approval

r 13, 2015
												Never in my life did I see myself playing poker, mother effing poker!Whenever I spot poker, It's either a $#!@ facebook or mobile game that is so plain and mundane I want to vomit.But this game, it's special, the depth and personality of the characters are just so funny and realistic, I won't blame you if you'd ditch your real life friends for these 4 lads, who may come out rude at times, but in the end they just want to have fun (Any your money)! That's not the only pro, there was just a big telltale sale you could get this game for less than a dollar, the unique and indulging gameplay+ the promotional tf2 items. It's true many people only buy it for the unlocks, but I myself still play it even after all the promotional weapons/cosmetics, the game's just that good to leave. Plus, it's a telltale game, you should expect quality and fun for hours if not days.The only con would be the limited playtime, as the game can be a bit short and boring after haring all the dialogue and obtaining all the items. To mostly avoid this for the most part I'd suggest taking moderate breaks and trying to enjoy yourself, and not hunt for the items. Good luck, good day, and have fun!

er 15, 2014
												Such a funny game! Takes the seriousness and enjoyment of Poker and removes the stress with fun tables and cards and absolutely HILARIOUS lines. I'd recommend removing the censor, but that's just my preference... Tycho swears a **** ton. It can get a little frustrating after you lose a few games in a row or when you're trying to get a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ straight flush, but it's enjoyable in other ways. You don't ACTUALLY lose money! You can enjoy poker without stress! The other guys say some really funny lines! And, of course, the reason why 60% of you buy this game - the TF2 items! A police badge, a sweet pistol, some slick shades, "Sasha" and a bloody watch. But this game isn't just about the TF2 items. I bought it because I wanted to enjoy it, and took the items as a bonus. It is quite fun to strategise how to win the game and how to target a certain item without ****ing up, and that feeling when you get a flush, a full house or a straight and you destroy everyone else's hands, or when you win with a pair of twos. This game is so much more than $5 of TF2 items! Highly recommend!!

												Poker Night was a very enjoyable experience. It is easily the best Texas Hold'em game I've ever played, as it provides a cast of humerous and interesting characters from various other games. Those unfamiliar with the customs and strategies that come with high stakes Poker may find the game difficult at times, but this is a game well worth it's asking price. The absense of any multiplayer was disapointing, and it doesn't make an appearance in it's sequel either.Those hoping to for 100% achievement unlocks in this game will be infuriated by one particular achievement requiring you to win a hand with a Straight Flush, which is a 0.0032% chance of happening with each hand. Completionists beware. :p

												This game features all-star characters duking it out in a battle of wits and cards. The game features very funny dialogue as well as some good TF2 unlockables that make this quirky little game well worth it's five dollar price tag.

y 13, 2014
												So the game is just your basic Texas Hold 'em, but the atmosphere is the selling point. Sitting down with the 4 characters, even if you don't know much about them to begin with, while they make interesting conversation with you and each other in a relaxing locale; that's what it's all about. Nice if you want a little break from all the fast paced do-or-die games you normally play.You can choose how often the characters talk, and if you want to speed up the actual game you can right-click to skip dialogue. You also have two difficulties to choose from, and you can unlock a few table felts and decks to add some more variety.There are some downsides though; you can't change the buy-in amount, how fast the blinds change, or make any tweaks to the actual game at all, so if you're a hard-core Hold 'em player this may turn you off. There's also no option for online play, and while that's mostly to be expected, having room for one friend to join in could have improved the life of the game quite a bit.Still, you can certainly put a number of hours into this one. Myself, I was only familiar with Strong Bad, and had never played Texas Hold 'em (and don't generally like playing cards period), but I still thoroughly enjoyed my experience with it, and it's priced low enough that you don't have much to lose.

15, 2013
												You know a lot of people ask me. "Chris, How do you win at online poker so you can obtain meaningless virtual items and sell them for ridiculous prices?" To which I answer "Go bribe that guy in the back alley to give you them." Moments later they all had the ban hammer dropped so hard their Steam accounts were warped through several dimensions. So now I tell them to play Poker Night at the Inventory. The game features some of the internets favorite characters and with a truck load of whitty dialouge poker has never seemed so interesting. TAKE THAT LATE NIGHT POKER TOURNIES!!! Plus you get items for TF2 thats a $400,000 profit for just $5.00!

Caveat emptor and all, but Telltale Games has soured this customer on their company, lost any future sales from this customer, and potentially lost future sales from all those I have the opportunity to relate my experience to.

												I give this game a thumbs up with qualifiers. If you:- Are looking for cheap, single-player poker game- Have a quirky sense of humor- Enjoy Max (from the Sam & Max games)- Know who Strong Bad is and think he's a cool guy- Don't mind idle chatter, and in fact enjoy itThen this is for you. If you aren't looking for a single-player poker game, don't care about Max, Strong Bad, or for that matter the Heavy from TF2 or Tycho from Penny Arcade, then maybe give this a pass. There's always Poker Night 2, which features Brock Samson, Claptrap, a weird version of Ash from Army of Darkness, and Sam from Sam & Max. Also GLaDOS as the dealer. Personally I recommend both, but this came first. Your mileage may vary, of course. (My low play time is due to the fact that I initially played it via my wife's library, before getting it myself.)

												Poker Night at the Inventory is an unique game in my point of view. Though, it is a gambling game alright. The characters are also very unique in personality. Unlockable Items From TF2:1. Dangeresque, Too? from Super Bad2. License to Maim and The Lugermorph from Max3. Iron Curtain from Heavy 4. Enthusiast's Timepiece from Tycho.With these characters in the game, it makes the whole game fun. There are 2 purposes that why people buy this game.1. To obtain the free items from the game.2. To enjoy the gameplay that was made to.I rather not uninstall this game after earning them all. So, take some time to play it regularly and experience the full Poker Night at the Inventory. 4 stars out of 5.

I have a Mac, and this worked out wonderfully for a while. Then, Mac 10.8 was released, and the game would now crash right after the tutorial. TTG refuses to patch the game, and urges those seeking refunds to go to Steam to request those refunds, knowing full well that Steam would not honor these refund requests.Instead of taking responsibility, TTG passed on the blame. Before, they did not mark a "maximum" system requirement and continued to sell a game that did not work for their customers.Instead of just fixing the game, now the requirements on Steam read "Not Compatible with Mac OS 10.8.x and above". I trust them about as far and I can throw them.

3, 2013
												An overall decent Texas Hold'em simulator, but the real stars here are your opponents, seeming almost randomly selected based on their backgrounds: Max from the Sam & Max franchise, Strongbad of Homestar Runner, The Heavy from Team Fortress 2, and Tycho of Penny Arcade. Telltale Games has outdone themselves creating an immersive experience with these third party characters, matching their personality to a T when it comes to dialogue and interactions: Max tells stories about fighting crime with Sam, Strongbad rants and raves just like with his email videos, Heavy thinks of the chips as his 'team' and blames the Spy whenever he gets a bad hand, and Tycho makes various different tabletop, card, and video game references. They play the game exactly like you would expect them to, which is a great feat in itself considering the licensing TTG must have had to go through. Even though Poker Night 2 is on the horizon and to be released this month, the original should not be overlooked. There are still special crossover TF2 items to be unlocked, and you won't be seeing any of the original cast (aside from cameos by Max) in the sequel. Definitely worth the buy.

ber 21, 2014
												People often say the price of something reflects its quality. I find that for the most part true, I mean Steam has a lot of crappy free to play games (*cough!* Spiral Knights *cough!*) but eventually you find ones worth your time. But if you want a game that will guarantee you a bit more enjoyment, premium games probably is where you will want to go. Poker Night at the Inventory is currently the first of three non-free to play games that I own and will review. So without anything else to say, let’s go!This game has a bland plot, but it’s better than nothing. The Inventory is an illegal gambling lounge founded in 1919 Mr. Kent after a draft of the 18th Amendment. Who or what is he? We’re never told. In the opening sequence we (the guy in the game) go down an elevator into the Inventory and this short dude with an admiral’s cap (Wikipedia says it’s Reginald Van Winslow, former captain of the Screaming Narwhal)comes recognizes us a noob. He leads us downstairs to a poker table. Playing is Heavy Weapons Guy from Team Fortress 2, Tycho from Penny Arcade comics, Strong Bad from Homestar Runner and Max from the Sam & Max games. The four let you into their game of no-limit Texas Hold ‘Em with stakes of $10, 000. Since no one seems to care that they are betting 10 grand, the game starts!Now into the game play. And...Its poker, what more is there to be said? Maybe the fact that during play characters will out of nowhere break into conversations and that are hilarious! The Heavy talking about TF2 game play and Max’s nonstop references to detective games in an innocent way. The more you go into the game, the more stuff you will unlock. There are minor differences like the cards and table icons changing to getting weapons for Team Fortress 2. At the beginning of some rounds, one of the characters will be broke and will put in a weapon to pay their fee. Knock them out and you will get their weapon. The Heavy has the Iron Curtain (minigun), Max has the Crimestopper Combo (Lugermorph – pistol and Licence to Maim - cosmetic), Strong Bad has the Dangeresque, Too? (cosmetic) and Tycho has the Enthusiast’s timepiece. After unlocking them, they will be yours to use in TF2.Aesthetically speaking, this game is not bad in terms of visuals. There are no glaring visual problems, but Steam has a lot prettier games. The music is all right, but not catchy.Poker Night at the Inventory is a good time in action, but is it for everyone? No. This game should be good for fans of Team Fortress 2, since playing will eventually have you starting to unlock new stuff. But for the 100 of you that don’t have Team Fortress 2, This is just another poker simulator. If you don’t care about the fancy stuff and just want to play Texas Hold ‘Em, find a poker game somewhere else because Poker Night at the Inventory simply won’t cater to you.My final verdict is that this game is great for its price, but for people seeking a proper poker simulator, there’s nothing to see here.

												I give this game a thumbs up with qualifiers. If you:- Are looking for cheap, single-player poker game- Have a quirky sense of humor- Enjoy Max (from the Sam & Max games)- Know who Strong Bad is and think he's a cool guy- Don't mind idle chatter, and in fact enjoy itThen this is for you. If you aren't looking for a single-player poker game, don't care about Max, Strong Bad, or for that matter the Heavy from TF2 or Tycho from Penny Arcade, then maybe give this a pass. There's always Poker Night 2, which features Brock Samson, Claptrap, a weird version of Ash from Army of Darkness, and Sam from Sam & Max. Also GLaDOS as the dealer. Personally I recommend both, but this came first. Your mileage may vary, of course. (My low play time is due to the fact that I initially played it via my wife's library, before getting it myself.)

												Such a funny game! Takes the seriousness and enjoyment of Poker and removes the stress with fun tables and cards and absolutely HILARIOUS lines. I'd recommend removing the censor, but that's just my preference... Tycho swears a **** ton. It can get a little frustrating after you lose a few games in a row or when you're trying to get a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ straight flush, but it's enjoyable in other ways. You don't ACTUALLY lose money! You can enjoy poker without stress! The other guys say some really funny lines! And, of course, the reason why 60% of you buy this game - the TF2 items! A police badge, a sweet pistol, some slick shades, "Sasha" and a bloody watch. But this game isn't just about the TF2 items. I bought it because I wanted to enjoy it, and took the items as a bonus. It is quite fun to strategise how to win the game and how to target a certain item without ****ing up, and that feeling when you get a flush, a full house or a straight and you destroy everyone else's hands, or when you win with a pair of twos. This game is so much more than $5 of TF2 items! Highly recommend!!

er 20, 2010
												If you've seen the clips of this game on YouTube, you likely know what you're going to expect.  You're also only getting about half the picture.  Shame on you.Poker Night offers a sincerely enjoyable, calm, mellow poker game that has one of the better AI engines for its genre.  It adapts, bluffs and amiably moves with you to add some genuine sense of risk and excitement, plus the colorful characters and general nostalgic charm give it a leg up over its general competition in the genre -- namely, your faceless 50-in-1 casino sims.  It's perfect for gamers and non-gamers who don't mind non-sequiters cracking their poker faces.  It's a casual game, yeah, but seldom has that ever been a bad thing.  When you're home sick from work, it's raining outside or you just don't feel up to twitch-shooters, this makes a nice companion to a cup of hot coffee and an afghan.  The shawl, not the ... yeah.

er 27, 2013
												"What would Heavy Weapons Guy have to say to Strong Bad in their off-hours?"  Not a lot as it turns out.  Telltale took a chance and made a poker game by licensing characters from other properties, and it works... for a while.  The dialogue is interesting and entertaining for the first couple hours, but loses its lustre as you hear the same things over and over.  Though once in a while, you'll get a new one and the surprise of new dialogue will make it extra funny.  If you're an achievement perfectionist, you'll end up with a lot of time in this one as the odds of some of the hands are 1:64,000.  Part of where this game stumbles is the choice of more obscure characters (Strong Bad, Tycho from Penny Arcade) which not everyone will be familiar with, though that's a minor point (and the characters in Poker Night 2 are more mainstream).Verdict:  Fun for a while, but recommend waiting for a 75% off discount.  After you're tired of the dialogue, play it in a window and watch Netflix, Hulu, or YouTube in another window.  Or pick up Poker Night 2 for the same price and have options for Texas and Omaha Hold 'Em instead of just Texas.

23, 2014
												This is an odd one to "beat," but there is a system somewhat a kin to boss battles. Each character will randomly buy in with special items. If you eliminate them from that tournament, you get their item, e.g. Max's badge and gun. So for purposes of cataloging, I'm going to say that getting all of those items is "beating" the game. It actually takes a fair amount of time for all of them to buy in with their items. The most disappointing thing about this game is that there is no multiplayer at all, which seems odd for a poker game. It's purely single player Texas Hold'em. There is a fair amount of dialog for each character, but you'll definitely hear it all multiple times prior to unlocking most of the achievements. It was a $5 game at launch though, so maybe it's a classic "you get what you pay for."

0, 2014
												As poker games go, this one is frustrating, slow, and the AI seems to lack any particular skill. I bought this because I'm a major Strong Bad fan, and on that front, I wasn't disappointed. Switching the options to make the characters more talkative gives you some interesting conversations to listen in to, and the interactions change depending on which characters have been knocked out of the tournament. There are genuinely funny laugh-out-loud moments, particularly if you've previously been acquainted with Strong Bad and Tycho.The problem is, even the converstation between players is randomly generated - that means that you'll sometimes watch them hold the same dialogue twice in the matter of a couple of minutes. Add to this that the players can't seem to make a single action (be that check, bet or fold) without delievering a Shakespearean-length soliloquy, showing down the play even further, and the voices start to lose their apppeal pretty quickly. Turning down the verbosity options doesn't actually help to speed things up, unfortunately. And the narrator likes to announce the hands and the winner of each pot with remarkable languidness... languiditude... lang..., la... SLOWNESS, and you can't skip him. The entertainment value is okay. But what you've really got here is a webseries with a lot of episodes with pop culture characters interacting in the context of a poker game. If the interactions were released as a series of 2-3 minute YouTube videos, I'd happily watch them all. But the AI is not well enough developed to make the game skillful, and the resulting luck-fest drags incredibly slowly. The computer can't recognise the difference between a minimum raise and a 6x bet, unless you push all-in. The other characters base their bets on the overall strength of their hand, with no concept of comparing their hand to others (that is, they seem to gladly go all-in when playing the board, regardless of their hole cards or possible kickers). I started playing with the difficulty on Hard, and this seems to translate as "Other players don't fold to your bets, making it a chase to the river, which you'll usually lose". Perhaps I'm being unfair.If you want a good, thinking man's poker game, look elsewhere. If you want to have a chuckle at Strong Bad being goaded by Heavy Weapons Guy, or Tycho checking with the delcaration "chkdsk", it's an entertaining way to spend some time. And I expect I will continue to play it for this reason, despite my frustrations with the play speed.Oh, and I've never played any of the Sam & Max games. But playing poker against Max today, I've realised that he's one annoying bunny, and I never want to see his face again. Jerk.

r 13, 2014
												Ah,Poker Night at the inventory.an very funny game.So let's do an review about it,shall we?The GameYou are playing against Homestar Runners from Superikone Strong Bad,Max from Sam & max,and the Heavy Weapons Guy(or short Heavy(Red)) from tf2(maybe missed 1 there).The game comes with new lines for each character, responses on certain situation. Thats supposed to make them look more alive, which it does,its very funny to see the face of the Heavy getting kicked out from the Table by either you or one of the other 3. But thats not the main part why many people play this Game.For each bounty you can win there,you get items,only optainable by playing that game,for Team Fortress 2 and Borderlands 2Yes,if you didn't knew that already well now you do.you can unlock hats 1 pistole replacemend and 1 spy watch replacemend too if i remember right(atleast for Team Fortress).and for Borderlands 2 some cosmetic for your characters.This game Costs 5€ on Steam,  and its worth it to give it a try.BUTOne big fact,which made it kinda bad,and reduced the play time for maybe the one or another hour,was how you earn these ItemsYou don't earn them by playing the matchs fully,they appear randomly  each time you start the game.Theres an,decent enough,chance of getting to win 1 of the 4 items,when one of them brings one in,you just have to win the match and kick everyone out of the Table.Now,i will NOT explain how that game exactly works,like the gamemodes, since its easy to learn(maybe you will have a bit of struggle in the beginning if you are completly new to it but it will stop after a while) Overall,Its an very funny Game,the downsides are,that you can easily win an game if you don't increase the difficulty,which isn't needed to win these items,and that they appear at pure random,making Winning without one not needed at all.Lukily,it is fixed in the next game,but more to that in the Review for it.I do recommend it, but if you aren't sure about it,wait until an discount is out for it and buy it then,since it might not be worth it for you in the end.But for both,the items you can get and playtime itself,its kinda worth it(if you want to play it just for the items,theres an easier way of getting them listed above,you can do it,but you don't have to)

												It's hard to comment on a game like this.  It's like commenting on the Solitaire game that came with my computer but I'll try.  As far as a poker game goes, it's great. r 13, 2014
												Ah,Poker Night at the inventory.an very funny game.So let's do an review about it,shall we?The GameYou are playing against Homestar Runners from Superikone Strong Bad,Max from Sam & max,and the Heavy Weapons Guy(or short Heavy(Red)) from tf2(maybe missed 1 there).The game comes with new lines for each character, responses on certain situation. Thats supposed to make them look more alive, which it does,its very funny to see the face of the Heavy getting kicked out from the Table by either you or one of the other 3. But thats not the main part why many people play this Game.For each bounty you can win there,you get items,only optainable by playing that game,for Team Fortress 2 and Borderlands 2Yes,if you didn't knew that already well now you do.you can unlock hats 1 pistole replacemend and 1 spy watch replacemend too if i remember right(atleast for Team Fortress).and for Borderlands 2 some cosmetic for your characters.This game Costs 5€ on Steam,  and its worth it to give it a try.BUTOne big fact,which made it kinda bad,and reduced the play time for maybe the one or another hour,was how you earn these ItemsYou don't earn them by playing the matchs fully,they appear randomly  each time you start the game.Theres an,decent enough,chance of getting to win 1 of the 4 items,when one of them brings one in,you just have to win the match and kick everyone out of the Table.Now,i will NOT explain how that game exactly works,like the gamemodes, since its easy to learn(maybe you will have a bit of struggle in the beginning if you are completly new to it but it will stop after a while) Overall,Its an very funny Game,the downsides are,that you can easily win an game if you don't increase the difficulty,which isn't needed to win these items,and that they appear at pure random,making Winning without one not needed at all.Lukily,it is fixed in the next game,but more to that in the Review for it.I do recommend it, but if you aren't sure about it,wait until an discount is out for it and buy it then,since it might not be worth it for you in the end.But for both,the items you can get and playtime itself,its kinda worth it(if you want to play it just for the items,theres an easier way of getting them listed above,you can do it,but you don't have to)

												The good points of this game might be the low price, the witty dialog and the TF2 items as rewards. Some rare dialog seems to occur in special cases too, such as when the heavy upturned the poker table.However the actual game is lacking, due to the substandard AI players. For instance, the AI tends to 'bluff' far to often, without even a pair after the flop. If you go out first and spectate the rest of the game, you'll see how often this happens.
