er 10, 2011
												Highly Recommend. Only 5 bucks, and you get a lot of fun playing No-limit Texas Holdem with some iconic video game/online culture figures, Including The Heavy class from TF2 (Team Fortress 2), Tycho Brahe from Penny Arcade, Strongbad from Homestar Runner, and Max from Sam and Max. As an added perk, if you defeat each player in a poker tournament, with their 'sprcial buy in', which are weapons, you get to use said weapons in TF2.

y 13, 2014
												So the game is just your basic Texas Hold 'em, but the atmosphere is the selling point. Sitting down with the 4 characters, even if you don't know much about them to begin with, while they make interesting conversation with you and each other in a relaxing locale; that's what it's all about. Nice if you want a little break from all the fast paced do-or-die games you normally play.You can choose how often the characters talk, and if you want to speed up the actual game you can right-click to skip dialogue. You also have two difficulties to choose from, and you can unlock a few table felts and decks to add some more variety.There are some downsides though; you can't change the buy-in amount, how fast the blinds change, or make any tweaks to the actual game at all, so if you're a hard-core Hold 'em player this may turn you off. There's also no option for online play, and while that's mostly to be expected, having room for one friend to join in could have improved the life of the game quite a bit.Still, you can certainly put a number of hours into this one. Myself, I was only familiar with Strong Bad, and had never played Texas Hold 'em (and don't generally like playing cards period), but I still thoroughly enjoyed my experience with it, and it's priced low enough that you don't have much to lose.

er 14, 2015
												Not a lot to say here. It's poker with a decent amount of banter between the players. The playstyle of the players mostly fits their character, though I never did figure out Max's playstyle. He was also the most fun of the characters banter-wise; Tycho is just a ♥♥♥♥ and not in any amusing way, and the Heavy and Strong Bad are both really one-note characters. The best moments are them playing off each other, and that's done fairly well, but eventually there's so little new dialogue left to hear that you're mostly stuck hearing the same things over and over.As for the gameplay, it's... poker. The AI is decent. I hardly noticed a difference between normal and hard. The only other gameplay thing I could mention are the achievements, which are... mostly luck-based. I'm not interested in grinding them out, at least, and I'm not really interested in playing this any further, either.For the low price point, I'd say it's worth it for a few hours of fun and banter, and you'd probably get more out of it if you were a poker nut, which I'm definitely not, but... yeah, alright.

, 2016
												I'm gonna keep this one short;  it's a single player poker game with funny banter that wears out its welcome in 2-3 hours.  Is it worth a purchse for $5?  Short answer, Yes with an if.  Long answer no, with a but.If you are a fan of any of these characters, it's worth the asking price.  If you're not, then it's not.  It doesn't do anything revolutionary.  There is no multiplayer mode, no online, no other modes.  There are a healthy amount of unlocks and great dialogue and interaction, though it cycles through everything in 3-5 hours, depending on table composition.Check it out;  it's something to do while the game is on and worth a chuckle or three.

												Just like TellTale's other poker game, "TellTale Texas Hold em" released in 2005, "Poker Night at the Inventory" is another bland, repitive entry in TellTale's attempt at a Poker game.The changes between "Poker Night" and "TellTale Texas Hold em" is a more interesting dialouge, table and card skins, and items for Team Fortress 2. The AI is still makes predictable choices and often, games can be won just by going all-in and forcing the AI to fold. Stick with Zynga's Texas Hold em game. At least you'll be playing against real humans, who, although at times mimic the AI in "Poker Night," will still be entertaining as you wipe out their banks.

er 2, 2013
												It's enjoyable. It's Texas Hold'em Poker - Nothing special there - and if you like that game, then this is a fine version of it. The opponents are characters of some note and provide humourous commentary, but after enough time playing the game, you'll have heard them all and all you'll want is for them to be silent, but there is sadly no option to silence them altogether so you'll have to settle for slightly less talkative. There are different difficulties, but they seem largely the same and are all fairly challengingThe game's a bit unoptimized and the soundtrack seems to be just that one song that repeats endlessly, but beyond the mind-numbing nature of repeatedly playing poker against the same enemies in the same environment with the same music, at least the varied commentary keeps it from eating away at one's sanity too much.The achievements are painful because they are dependent upon happening upon select poker hands at random and for exceedingly rare ones like four-of-a-kind, straight-flush, three-of-a-kind with Kings, it will likely require a lot of playing.One of the main reasons to get this game is for the Team Fortress 2 unlockable equipment which aren't terribly hard to get. Other unlockables in this game include in-game card-decks and table-tops. I question if this game is not cloud-save-enabled because, after reinstalling, all my progress from the last time it was installed was absent so I had to re-earn all of the unlocks.

ber 17, 2014
												Honestly I just bought the game because it was on sale once for 0,99€ and I was intrigued by the TF2 items. After playing for a while I realized that the game is more that just a cash-in on in-games items. It actually has a lot of humor and you'll probably get a good laugh from the dialog between the characters, if you know them of course.The TF2 awards are actually really satisfying to win, because it isn't just handed to you for buying the game. No, you have to win it. Thus making this game really enjoyable, it feels like you're actually getting something out of it. It drives you into wanting to win a poker match and dread losing because you have to start over again.Do not worry to much about not knowing poker, I still have no idea what I'm doing. The game actually helps you to understand a thing or two neatly without forcing you trough some dumb tutorial.5€ is still an okay price, you'll probably get a lot of fun out of it even if you're just in it for the TF2 stuff.8/10

15, 2016
												Poker Night at the Inventory is a simple concept, executed well. It takes a few well-known characters in the gaming/geek world, puts them together at a poker table, and you get to play poker with them. If you are at all familiar with Texas Hold-em poker, and don't find the game absolutely horrible, there is some fun to be had with this title. The main source of fun comes from the interactions between the different characters. If you know these characters, it makes the banter even better as you will be delighted to see their personalities are kept true to their source material. It's like playing poker with some semi-celebrities: no more, no less.6/10 "Okay"

er 16, 2014
												Definitely one of Telltale Games must haves. The game itself runs well and the mechanics are the same as with any other Texas Hold 'Em Poker game you would run in to, but what makes this game worthwhile is the characters you play against. Max, The Heavy, Strong Bad & Tycho share hilarious, well-written banter between each other and the player, making it fun to stick around and play just to see what they will start babbling about next. Obviously a fair amount of banter is humour and in-jokes from their respective games/web-series, but is done in a way so it is still amusing to those who are not familiar with their respective Franchises. Another nice touch is the range of reactions the characters have to actions the player has. For example going All-In, depending on the situation, can cause the whole table to turn and look at you with suprise and shout. Alternitively the characters will also act smug if they have the upper hand, or get angry or frustrated if you are winning that hand. All in all, this is one of the most funny and interesting Poker Sims to play, and worth having for the occasional hand of Poker, with a table of characters who are very much, insane.

												I would now warn all people buying all Telltale Games. This game was so much fun, and I love poker, so I bought it hoping to have a quick and fun poker game to play casually. I have a Mac, and this worked out wonderfully for a while. Then, Mac 10.8 was released, and the game would now crash right after the tutorial. TTG refuses to patch the game, and urges those seeking refunds to go to Steam to request those refunds, knowing full well that Steam would not honor these refund requests.Instead of taking responsibility, TTG passed on the blame. Before, they did not mark a "maximum" system requirement and continued to sell a game that did not work for their customers.Instead of just fixing the game, now the requirements on Steam read "Not Compatible with Mac OS 10.8.x and above". I hope you read that, because otherwise you dropped $4.99 down the proverbial toilet.I'm just waiting to see what other flaw or oversight they choose to ignore in the future. I trust them about as far and I can throw them.

												Pokr Night at the Inventory is a game about - Well, poker. You play at a place called the Inventory, Kinda like a bar for video game characters. Probably the main aesthetic to this game is that you play with four players, all from different games. Even if you (Somehow) dont know any of these people its still a great and worthwhile expirience. Fortunatly, unlike most card games out there, its not stale and boring. The characters chat and make references to their own or other peoples games, which I liked ALOT. And with quirky animations, customisation of decks, varing difficulty, trading cards and achievments - all at a low price, you'd be stupid not to pick up this title.You also get free tf2 Stuff.Basically why 90% of people buy it.Not even kidding.

1, 2011
												Filled with absurb humour and fun poker playing at a reasonable price, Poker Night at The Inventory is a good game for anyone who is a fan of poker, Homestar Runner, Sam 'n Max, Penny Arcade or Team Fortress 2. Perhaps especially so with Team Fortress 2. The game features several interesting (if cosmetic) unlockables at less than Mann Co. Store prices, when taken all together. Combined with the fact that you're getting a free game, it's worth it to any 'hard-core' TF2 fan. Besides, you may find you enjoy the game of Texas Hold'Em on its own merits.As for me, I think the biggest factor going for the game is the humor value. The characters are lovable, the unlocks good for a giggle or two, but overall, the conversations are the most interesting aspect of this game. I sincerely hope there will be a sequel, preferably with a few more characters. (TF2 Unlocks optional, frankly.)While I am blue skying though, I wish people would buy in with collateral after you have already won it.

The problem is, it doesn't work with newer macs! it's a few years old too so i thought they would've updated it. every time i click the done button right after it explains the rules, it crashes! i looked into it and found a few interesting guides to what works and what doesn't.Poker Night at the Inventory on Mac computers is only compatible with OS X 10.5.x through 10.7.5. If you experience a crash on OS X 10.8.x or above, please try running the game on a compatible Mac or PC computer.Hi, I recently bought this game and quickly found out that after clicking the "done" button on the tutorial, the whole game falls apart and crashes, I browsed along some threads on steam and found that this crash problem happens to a lot of other people. I also found out that this problem has been going on for a long time. I later saw that Poker Night at the Inventory is "not compatible with Mac OS 10.8 and above", to which I ask, WHY? Does this mean we have to downgrade our macs just so we can play this game? I have OS X Yosemite, and I am not gonna downgrade my mac just so I can play this game. I also found out that TellTale games has not made any plans regarding to fixing this problem, to which I ask again, WHY? Lion: Crash after rules of poker are explainedLate 2012 Macbook Pro - OSX Mt. Lion: Crash after rules of poker are explainedGateway NV Series - Windows 7: Crashed on install initially, now runs okay, but slowlyDell Latitude - Windows XP: No problems, runs really wellAll computers have at least 4 gigs of RAM and i5 Processors, except for the Gateway which is a dual-core.I'm thinking it's possibly OSX Mt. Lion related since they're the only computers that can't run it at all.If you bought it and can't play it, just try to get a refund. it's just a regular poker game. ry 21, 2013
												This backroom Poker tournament simulator of sorts is one of those games that I wouldn't have expected to grow quite so much on me. Granted, playing Poker against artificial intelligence doesn't entail the same satisfaction that one gets from successfully bluffing or showing a superior hand to fellow human players, however the entertainment value here lies within the often satirical, tongue-in-cheek and cleverly crass character dialogue and interactions with one another, complimented by the appropriately ambient visuals and music. To enjoy the spoken content at its best, be sure to enable maximum chatter in the options menu. I personally relish the sense of humor in this game, and will sometimes just sit idly at the virtual table simply watching and listening to the banter going back and forth; from Heavy's uncharacteristically tender and touching anecdote of a sparrow encountered back at Motherland, to Tycho's eyebrow-raising fantasies of intimately bonding with particular species of animals.When set to Easy, this game offers a fun way for players who are new to the Texas Hold 'em variant of Poker to grasp its fundamentals, however in order to get proper practice it's ultimately best to experience playing against real people with their own individual tactical mindsets as opposed to fictional characters with preset and non-unique betting behaviors.

												Fun when your bored, a decent poker simulation with a video game twist, only issue is the game encourages you to buy everyone drinks to get them to show hints about their cards.  While the idea is great, the actual results are not, the players give little to no increase in body language, and the few movements they do make tell litterally nothing.  This makes the game a challenge at times and is largely based on luck.  But besides that I quite enjoyed the game even though the reason I bought it was the tf2 items.  The characters have their respective personalities but as with real humans they can be quite unpredictable.  One minute you might bluff and go all in and everyone folds, then you do it again in an entirely different game and everyone goes all in too and you get completely demolished.  It's one game where the RNG system is actually fun.  7.92/10 -Scale of edgy approval

28, 2016
												What's there to say about Poker Night at the Inventory?It's a fun poker game that you can just jump into whenever you want, to play with the four hilarious characters. It teaches you how to play poker casually very quickly, which is fun, though I think that an online multiplayer where you can just pick one of the four characters and play with three friends would be a very good addition to the game. The only real "complaint" I have with this game is that the smalltalk the characters make gets quite repetitive and boring very quickly, but that's about it.Overall, very fun if you want to play something different for once.7,5/10

												I actually played the Poker Night games out of order, since I only discovered them this year, and my Mac was too new to play the original.  I recently set up a Windows system, partly just to try this title, to see how it compared to Poker Night 2.I was glad to see that the fundamentals--the music, the ambiance, the banter, the general coolness--are just as strong.  Poker Night 2 is slightly fancier, but everything that makes it enjoyable is in the original.  I did, however, find the cast to be a bit less interesting than the sequel's, Max notwithstanding.In general I'm glad to have Poker Night 2's experience continued, if backward.

ber 7, 2016
												There's lots of free high quality single-player poker games available these days, so why should you pay for this one? What sets it apart?Two things. First, you get to play against four colorful, interesting opponents. Second, there's a fun unlock system in which you can earn new decks and tables. This has no effect on gameplay, but does give you a feeling of accomplishment.Bad things. The game frames per second is sometimes poor. I'm playing on Windows 7 64 bit and my computer has no problem running modern games. So a six year old game like this really shouldn't ever be stuttering. It's still very playable though.Also, after about a dozen games you'll have heard all of the voice chatter of your opponents and it'll start to become repetitive. You do have the option to reduce voice chatter or turn it off, however.It took me 16 hours to unlock everything and at a cost of only 5 bucks I can't complain. If you're looking for a colorful poker game this might be for you!

ber 11, 2016
												A slow paced, repetitive poker game with few laughs and no challenge whatsoever.I like a single player experience but this one doesn't bring much to the virtual poker table. Most of the jokes fall flat and start repeating before the end of the first game. The lowest dialogue frequency setting still isn't low enough. And while being able to skip to the end of hands you fold, the game goes at a snail's pace. Which on paper seems okay for a poker game, and the characters you play do indeed seem to give off reads or clues about what cards they are holding. But I never bothered learning them. The randomness that would be a shuffled deck of playing cards doesn't feel so random here. Even on hard the odds seem stacked well in your favor as long as you play even half smart. The game is extremely easy. So then it circles back and the pacing just comes off as too slow trying to click away to the inevitable win.I liked the concept but it didn't work. I still don't know who the unlikable "Tycho" character is suppose to be. And supposedly you can unlock Team Fortress 2 items if you play that game. I don't. Beyond killing a couple hours the game didn't offer up much beyond the concept. Delivery fell flat for me. I see there is a sequel but nothing happened here to pique my interest there. Perhaps as a mild introduction to Texas Hold'em in an amusing way it could work, but I don't know if that niche exists nowadays. Priced right for what it is but still not worth it outside of a bundle for me.

er 27, 2013
												"What would Heavy Weapons Guy have to say to Strong Bad in their off-hours?"  Not a lot as it turns out.  Telltale took a chance and made a poker game by licensing characters from other properties, and it works... for a while.  The dialogue is interesting and entertaining for the first couple hours, but loses its lustre as you hear the same things over and over.  Though once in a while, you'll get a new one and the surprise of new dialogue will make it extra funny.  If you're an achievement perfectionist, you'll end up with a lot of time in this one as the odds of some of the hands are 1:64,000.  Part of where this game stumbles is the choice of more obscure characters (Strong Bad, Tycho from Penny Arcade) which not everyone will be familiar with, though that's a minor point (and the characters in Poker Night 2 are more mainstream).Verdict:  Fun for a while, but recommend waiting for a 75% off discount.  After you're tired of the dialogue, play it in a window and watch Netflix, Hulu, or YouTube in another window.  Or pick up Poker Night 2 for the same price and have options for Texas and Omaha Hold 'Em instead of just Texas.

0, 2014
												As poker games go, this one is frustrating, slow, and the AI seems to lack any particular skill. I bought this because I'm a major Strong Bad fan, and on that front, I wasn't disappointed. Switching the options to make the characters more talkative gives you some interesting conversations to listen in to, and the interactions change depending on which characters have been knocked out of the tournament. There are genuinely funny laugh-out-loud moments, particularly if you've previously been acquainted with Strong Bad and Tycho.The problem is, even the converstation between players is randomly generated - that means that you'll sometimes watch them hold the same dialogue twice in the matter of a couple of minutes. Add to this that the players can't seem to make a single action (be that check, bet or fold) without delievering a Shakespearean-length soliloquy, showing down the play even further, and the voices start to lose their apppeal pretty quickly. Turning down the verbosity options doesn't actually help to speed things up, unfortunately. And the narrator likes to announce the hands and the winner of each pot with remarkable languidness... languiditude... lang..., la... SLOWNESS, and you can't skip him. The entertainment value is okay. But what you've really got here is a webseries with a lot of episodes with pop culture characters interacting in the context of a poker game. If the interactions were released as a series of 2-3 minute YouTube videos, I'd happily watch them all. But the AI is not well enough developed to make the game skillful, and the resulting luck-fest drags incredibly slowly. The computer can't recognise the difference between a minimum raise and a 6x bet, unless you push all-in. The other characters base their bets on the overall strength of their hand, with no concept of comparing their hand to others (that is, they seem to gladly go all-in when playing the board, regardless of their hole cards or possible kickers). I started playing with the difficulty on Hard, and this seems to translate as "Other players don't fold to your bets, making it a chase to the river, which you'll usually lose". Perhaps I'm being unfair.If you want a good, thinking man's poker game, look elsewhere. If you want to have a chuckle at Strong Bad being goaded by Heavy Weapons Guy, or Tycho checking with the delcaration "chkdsk", it's an entertaining way to spend some time. And I expect I will continue to play it for this reason, despite my frustrations with the play speed.Oh, and I've never played any of the Sam & Max games. But playing poker against Max today, I've realised that he's one annoying bunny, and I never want to see his face again. Jerk.

												Simply put, a good poker game. Has all the elements to it: Risk, Reward, Relaxing, and Hilarious. Putting characters with certain experiences makes a funny and entertaining passtime. If anyone likes poker or these characters than they should really buy the game and give it a try. With Max, Tycho, The heavy and the... red guy who i forgot... oh yes, Strongbad. They all have experiences they can brag about or be embarrased about, which when brought up by another player gives a certain reaction makes the game feel real. They can also talk to YOU. They can simply tell you to fold, and bet, or they can be irritated if you take too long to select an option. I like the character immersion in this game, and it definitely felt casual when i played this game. For anyone who wants to make good characters, you should really look at how characters can interact with each other and display their emotions and personality like in this game. Good game which i highly recommend.

er 4, 2014
												Poker Night at the Inventory is a great game for non-Poker players to learn the game.  It can be a little daunting, but playing around with three loveable characters and Tycho can really help one learn the game.  It's got a brief tutorial, but most of what you'll learn is obtained through trial and error.The TF2 bonus items are pretty sweet, and for a lot of people, it's the reason they picked up the game.My only real quarrel with Poker Night is the achievements.  Whoever assigned those needs to be dragged out in the street, tarred, then feathered.  Over half of the achievements are entirely luck based (specifically winning a hand with a particular hand of cards, requiring you to first get that hand, and then pray to whatever supernatural influence you prefer that nobody else has a better one.)For one particular example, the Straight Flush achievement has a 1-in-Thousands chance (specific number depends on who you ask it seems), and that's assuming you play every hand to the end without folding, no matter the risk.  Needless to say, seeking this achievement *will* cost you a lot of tourneys, not to mention a lot of wasted time and wear on your mouse in clicking through everything.I'd recommend this game to anyone who wants to learn Texas Hold 'Em, enjoys getting TF2 items, and is NOT fussed about achievements.

												I'm gonna keep this one short;  it's a single player poker game with funny banter that wears out its welcome in 2-3 hours.  Is it worth a purchse for $5?  Short answer, Yes with an if. 30, 2016
												I'mma be straight forward here: Only 2 of the main 4 characters you play Texas Hold 'Em Against I actually know of, only because of their popularity of their franchises (Sam and Max, and TF2), the other two aren't as popular or well known, so that's one flaw. Two, the item system is complete random, so it could take at least 10 minutes of you either restarting the match just for one of them to offer an item instead of money in the beginning cutscene, or try and be VERY patient and keep losing/ winning until one of them offers an item. HOWEVER, even if they do offer one, if you lose your entire hand, or they lose theirs to someone ELSE, you won't get the item. Anyways, the main flaws are: Poor random choice in a few characters, overall game mechanics, and the lack of weapons in the game that actually have use, like stat-weapons like the Spy-cicle, and the only cool item you unlock (personally in my opinion) is the Enthusiast's Timepiece. What would have made this much better, is if all characters were always random TF2 characters, with them betting items more often (since the weapons won in the games go into your TF2 file). I wouldn't really recommend it, since the only main reason why I got the game (from a trade) was because I wanted the Timepiece watch because let's be honest here, who wouldn't want a SOLID GOLD invisibility watch, that has a symbol representing video games' most iconic character of all time, PAC-MAN!? Overall, 4/10.

												I originally bought it for the tf2 items, but then realized its actually a really fun game. Though i wasnt playing for fun until after i got the items since they can be hard to get if you dont have a good hand.Good:-Funny and entertaining dialogue between the characters-Free items! (that is, unless you bought this game solely for the items)-if you lose a game you can watch the rest of them finish it if you want to,and the best part? you get to see their hands!-You can unlock many tables and decks to customize your game (doesnt affect gameplay of course,but still cool.)-you get a little poker nickname after each win (or loss) depending on how much you have (or owe)Bad:- fresh dialogue seems to run out after about 2 hours and most lines repeat, though some new lines still pop up here and there.Tips:-If you are here for the items but dont want to play normal games, press Escape go to the menu and keep clicking new tournament, keep clicking it until somone doesnt throw money and throws an item in instead-if your playing a normal game try to knockout tycho first because trust me you DO NOT want to be alone at the table with tycho, he will put you through hell.Overall: Just a very fun game, especially for just 5$

Amazing when you are low on moneyRaise: Raise the money in the pot.bet: lose money but if you when the hand you get all the money you lost and more!ALL IN!: Remove all your money that you have (as a bonus: tycho might swear if you do this on the first turn.

												I am an active player of Team Fortress 2 and I always saw players weilding these weapons like the Lugermorph or the Iron Curtain. But I never understood where they got these very nice items from. I decided to do some research on google because it bothered me a lot and found out about this game. I instantly bought it because I wanted to get the Lugermorph and show my friends because I thought it was a very cool pistol skin. I jumped right into the game, and I barely even know how to play poker or Texas hold 'em, but I had gotten the hang of it. I just kept restarting the game until Max, Strong Bad, Heavy, or Tycho to reveal one of  their items. But the first Item I got was the watch (Forgot what it was called). and soon after I got all of the other Items: "Iron Curtain", "Lugermorph" and "Licence to Maim", and lastly "Dangeresque, Too?" (the glasses). I opened up Team Fortress 2 and the game rewarded me with my Items. If you are an active Team Fortress 2 player like me I highly recommend this game to you. And I am also looking forward to "Poker Night 2" for any more items. So to sum up the entire review it is a very rewarding game and for a TF2 player looking for cool brand-new items to get this is the game! And also it is a fun poker game :)

er 18, 2010
												This game's sense of style is intoxicating. Fifteen years ago, this would have been Multimedia Celebrity Poker, but today we get Poker Night at the Inventory. Life is good.Before the introduction was finished, I was sold on the setting of the Inventory. From the beautifully textured "Kent Games & Amusements" background on the statistics screen to the main characters' idle animations after they are eliminated from play, everything feels wonderfully authentic.Af far as the poker mechanics are concerned, I do notice that the AI makes an occasional check-raise or folds with everything but a few hundred chips in the pot. I'm sure these things detract from the game's potential as a training simulation, but as far as I'm concerned they don't detract from its overall playability.Definitely pick this up if you're interested in hanging out with a group of unique characters over a few hundred rounds of poker in a well-crafted and enigmatic setting.

												I'm gonna keep this one short;  it's a single player poker game with funny banter that wears out its welcome in 2-3 hours.  Is it worth a purchse for $5?  Short answer, Yes with an if.  Long answer no, with a but.If you are a fan of any of these characters, it's worth the asking price.  If you're not, then it's not.  It doesn't do anything revolutionary.  There is no multiplayer mode, no online, no other modes.  There are a healthy amount of unlocks and great dialogue and interaction, though it cycles through everything in 3-5 hours, depending on table composition.Check it out;  it's something to do while the game is on and worth a chuckle or three.

												Alright I'll just save everyone's sanity and keep the review of this game short. Poker Night at the Inventory is basically just a bog standard poker game with a couple of funny characters. Strong Bad, Max, Heavy and Tycho make some funny jokes along the way and it's almost enough to distract you from the game.Almost.The massive flaw with Poker Night at the Inventory is that it's only defining feature over any other poker game is the characters you play against. The game itself is a boring game of poker that becomes mind numbing very quickly. Buy this game on sale, read a guide that tells you how to get all the items and either refund it or uninstall it.

er 27, 2012
												Fanservice. This game is a big helping of fanservice; but who said fanservice was always a bad thing? The dialogue that goes on between the Heavy, Tycho, Max, and Strong Bad has a "real" quality to it. It's as if you really just joined a poker game with them. Fanservice aside, it's just a Texas Hold 'Em game. Only two difficulties (normal and hard) are present. However, there are a wide array of tables and card decks that are unlocked as you win games to spice things up a bit.  There are also unlockables for Team Fortress 2.  They don't have any special stats, but they do look nice. If you're not into poker or gambling, I'd pass this up. That being said, I do recommend it to anyone half-decent at card games or if you want the tf2 stuff. On a related note, the fanservice feel wears off after a little bit of gameplay (like a new car smell...strange analogy, but it works). Conversations will be repeated and it will lose that magic that captivated you in the first place. Ultimately, it's a decent poker game that's well worth the money.

y 28
												You know what would be a very nice feature to a game with a very complicated theme? A tutorial. Something this game lacks. It's willing to tell you interesting facts about how Texas Hold'Em was created but it will tell you jack ♥♥♥♥ about how to play it, what cards are bad or good, or even if there IS a way to be good at it. I actually had to look up online how the ♥♥♥♥ Texas Hold'Em works and there are very, very few explanations online that can give you a basic understanding of how this works. You just play the game and hope you win from my standpoint. While were at it let's make a game about Russian Roulette.

ry 17
												I didn't know how to play poker, but its pretty easy. If you easily want to get the TF2 items follow my instructions, step one start a game (if there is no cutscene where one of the opponents throws in a item (NOT MONEY) return to menu and start a new game)once a opponent throws in a item wait there turn (if they fold you fold) (if they put money into the pot) you go all in, they should go all in too, you should have a big chance to get that item but if you lose the item try again, (rinse and repeat).Enjoy your TF2 items, and thank you for reading this review!
